subtitle: The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed
magazine was just released on March 1st.
You can download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed Foundation website.
That's newthinkingallowed.org.
You can even order a printed copy from nta-magazine.magcloud.com.
Thinking Allowed – conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today our topic is grandmother ayahuasca.
We're going to look at the shamanistic realities,
the magic and the mysteries associated with
the use of ayahuasca.
With me is Dr. Rachel Harris, who is a psychologist
and the author of Listening to Ayahuasca – New
Hope for Depression, Addiction, PTSD, and Anxiety.
Welcome again, Rachel.
Thank you, Jeffrey.
It's a pleasure to be with you.
You know, throughout your book you refer to grandmother ayahuasca not as a metaphor but
as a living being and I have to say a spiritual
presence who has been a real force in your
life and who was also, since you are a Western-trained
psychologist, also the source of an existential
crisis.
Yes, for me.
Not for other people.
Other people I've interviewed and they don't
seem to have any conflict over being in a
relationship with the spirit of the plant.
But for me, it's difficult for me.
Well, because of course you're also reporting to your professional colleagues.
It's a little embarrassing to talk about it.
You know, I did – the research I did was
published and I had a co-author and the co-author
was one of my research mentors who came out
of a 30-year retirement to do this study with
me.
And as we were getting close to publication,
I said to him, you know, there really should
be a third author here.
And he understood completely what I meant.
Yeah, we did receive help from grandmother ayahuasca and he was aware of it.
We worked with the information she gave us
and it made a difference in how we interpreted
the statistical findings.
I mean, I can't say it without laughing about it.
And of course, every Western-trained psychologist
is trained to assume that when you're referring
to a spiritual being, you're really just
projecting your own inner subconscious dynamics.
Right.
This must be my own inner voice.
But I really assert – I've done a lot of inner work – this was not my own voice.
I really knew that.
And as much as I have a difficulty accepting
the reality of it, I have to say that I've
dedicated the last ten years of my life to
carrying out what I felt was her mission that
she gave me.
And I really rose to the occasion to do it.
It's been a lot of work.
And at one point, somebody asked me if I was working on my dissertation.
And I said, no, no, I did that 30 years ago.
This is not my dissertation.
I'm doing this for the fun of it.
I did it in response to what I heard.
In other words, she told you.
Literally, the words were, do the research.
Now, she didn't give me any more instructions than that.
So I had certainly a lot of free – I just didn't doubt it at all.
I just did the research.
I did it the way that it made sense to me.
So it wasn't like she told me exactly what to do, but it was clear to do the research.
Well, people who use ayahuasca and other psychedelics
often report entering into a magical world,
a world that's very different from normal, Western, everyday consensus reality.
Right.
That's true.
Especially academic reality.
Yes, that's more so true.
Even more so because, let's face it, as a
parapsychologist, I can tell you most people
believe in ESP and psychic experiences and
the spiritual world and survival after death.
It's just the guardians of our culture who say that these things are not acceptable,
at least from a scientific perspective.
Guardians of the priests would say they're not acceptable unless our religion approves
of them.
Yes, there's that caveat.
I really believe – this is where I really feel strongly – that as a culture, we need
to be more accepting of these altered states.
The Gallup poll and the Pew Research group asked
a random selection of the general population,
have you had a spiritual or mystical experience?
Half the people say yes, but they're not talking about it.
And so it hasn't changed the culture, but half the people, one out of two, you would
think that would change the culture to be more open to these unusual experiences.
But if people are not talking about it, then
the general public doesn't really know about
it.
Well, it's one of the reasons that I do this video
interview series, is to keep the conversation
going.
Yes.
Thank you.
We'll do that.
Yeah.
And of course, your work with people who have
experienced ayahuasca is that almost, I think
you said, 75% of them have reported a personal experience.
I'm going, relationship.
Personal relationship with a spiritual mentor who happens to be a plant.
Yes, a plant spirit.
We hardly even know how to talk about it.
Yeah.
Yes, it's a little mind-blowing.
Yeah, of all the findings in the research
study, that was the one that was the biggest
surprise.
I understood that people improved psychologically
in many ways and also became more spiritual,
more interested in being closer to nature.
People would want to move to live in a closer
relationship to nature, but that they had
this ongoing relationship with this plant spirit was, for me, mind-blowing.
Well, and surely many people listening to a conversation like this are tempted to think
to themselves what idiots they are.
Except I'm one of them.
Yeah.
Well, let me just give you my take on it.
I think you wrote about this in your book as
well, William James, great scholar, psychologist,
student of religion, wrote about God this way.
He said, God exists ontologically based on pragmatic criteria.
American pragmatism is basically that if it works, it's true.
Yes.
God, therefore, exists because people who have God in their life have that experience
of an ongoing relationship.
You see the effect.
Right.
You see the effects.
That's real.
That's undeniable.
Well, I think this qualifies.
There was a quote from Stan Grof that I included
because he is one of these people who's had
a wide range of experiences, shall we say.
And he said what was unique about his ayahuasca experience was this relationship.
And he called it a therapeutic relationship.
And I think that is what's unique about this medicine.
Not that it's the only one.
As you pointed out earlier, peyote, there's
grandfather peyote and some of the other plants
have spirits as well.
But of the psychedelics, this one is really prominent.
And every shamanistic tradition around the
world involves having a personal relationship
with spirit beings.
Yes.
And there is this ongoing process of discernment
with receiving help from spiritual beings,
from spirit beings.
See, I can hardly, I stutter, I can hardly say it.
But there was one quote from a shaman who, this is an elderly shaman, I mean, he's now
over a hundred.
And so there's translation involved here.
But he was asked, how do I know what my decision should be?
And he said, talk to the spirits.
So there's this ongoing relationship.
And a number of people I interviewed were literally living their lives based on what
they felt was the guidance they were getting spiritually.
And you know, that's a little, it's a little out there for me.
I mean, I do, in my own life decisions, I think
about things a little bit more methodically.
But these people were really following what
they felt was their intuitive spiritual advice
that they were getting from these sources.
You know, in order to have a relationship with a spirit teacher, one needs to have a
lot of trust.
Yes.
And it's a strong belief.
But it's an experiential belief.
It's based on experience.
I'm under the impression that there can be authentic spirits who are not trustworthy.
Yes, and you know, I interviewed someone from,
it wasn't an ayahuasca circle, it was the,
it was a, I can't remember which, it'll eventually come to me, it's from Cuba.
It's one of the spiritual groups from Cuba.
And I said, how do you know what spirits to
listen to and what to let in to be incorporated?
And he looked at me as if I were a complete
idiot, which of course I am with this question.
And he said, we clear the space so that only good spirits can enter.
So that kind of, that did the vetting process ahead of time.
And shamans clear the space as well.
So that there is some sense of discerning which spirits to work with and which ones
not to.
But that's beyond my pay grade, that's beyond my psychology degree.
Yeah, I think it's fair to say that when you
become really proficient at anything, whether
it's business or ballet, you're going to develop
sensitivities to the subtleties and to the
nuances of what you're doing that go way beyond
the ability of the average person to discriminate.
Right, that's true.
Yes, that's true, especially in the arts, where things are very subjective and very
subtle often, but people make very fine distinctions.
You know, I had the opportunity, well, with
my daughter growing up, I had the opportunity
to sit in on many rehearsal sessions with
her, and I don't know if you read about this
in the book, but many different classical voice situations.
And the most recent one is she's at the Metropolitan Opera with the chorus.
So this is the top choral director in the world, basically.
And he's making these very fine corrections.
So in a group of, there are 80 members of the
Metropolitan Opera Chorus, and he'll point
to one person.
And I'm sitting in the room, God forbid I should be singing, I'm sitting in the seats
next to my daughter, and he points to one person because he hears that there he wants
something different from them, I have no clue.
It's just, it is as if he's hearing from a different world.
And it's that refined a perceptive ability.
And in this country, we sort of have forgotten that apprenticeship process.
And that's how this conductor, he's almost 70 now, that's how he was trained.
He did not come out of a conservatory.
He was apprenticed to conductors.
And so this skill was developed over decades.
And we forget how long someone needs to sweep
the floor in the craft studio before they
can actually even start to throw a pot, for instance.
And it's a very long process.
And it's fair to assume that shamans who enter
into the realm of spirit, some of them, at
least, will have the same subtlety of
discrimination as this renowned choral conductor.
Yes, yes, I'm sure they do, in their avenue.
And one of the, part of the, I don't know how
to say this any better, part of the graduation
ceremony for one shaman was that there were
three elder shamans watching him as he worked
with people.
And they had to agree on the diagnosis and the treatment.
So there's a real test for this.
And yes, and it's mind-boggling how perceptual ability can be so refined.
But this was your experience throughout your
engagement with the ayahuasca rituals, traditions?
I'm a beginner with my perceptual training in these realms.
I am a clumsy beginner.
So I am receiving help and learning to be more gracious and accepting about it.
I mean, there was one point where I was in the midst of writing, and of course I was
behind on my deadline, and I was writing about
the most scientific parts of the neurological
findings.
And I was bemoaning the fact that I was probably
two people away from the Dalai Lama, but I
didn't know anybody who knew a cognitive scientist who was familiar with ayahuasca.
A week later, I had a professor from Berkeley
who was willing to read my chapter for me.
And he had experience both as a neuroscientist and with ayahuasca.
I mean, he was probably the only one on the
planet practically, and he vetted that chapter
for me.
But that, I mean, that felt like help to me.
Well, John Lilly, who was also a psychedelic
pioneer, talked about, echo, I think, was
his phrase, earth coincidence control.
And again, it's part of the workings of grandmother
ayahuasca or other highly evolved guides from
the inner realms.
I think you used the phrase the imaginal realms, which I like a lot.
With an imagination.
And that's not my phrase.
That's Henri Corban, a French philosopher who studied Sufism.
That's his description.
And I like it a lot.
But in this realm, the ability to kind of engineer synchronicities seems to exist.
Yes, it does.
And I was grateful for the help I got with that synchronicity.
There is this sense, you know, in the last
chapter where I talk, where I reach for this,
this part of the mystery, is I quoted about a dozen poems, because it's the poets who
have a way of capturing, and there's this
one phrase, the mountain behind the mountain,
the pointing to other worlds, other realities,
that what we see here is just one aspect,
that there are other worlds coinciding with this world.
And so there's some perceptual training that opens those other worlds.
And certainly ayahuasca opens portals to other worlds.
It's most reliably known as being the vine of the spirits.
So the spirit world opens up, and people are
able to communicate with people who have died.
And so one thing I have to say is my relationship
with people whom I have lost, those relationships
have greatly improved.
I mean, I'm talking about a living relationship
with somebody who died now 40 years ago almost.
And yet I feel my friend's presence, this is
someone I grew up with, so it was a childhood
friend, I feel the presence of this person
more strongly now as a result of the ayahuasca
ceremonies.
So there's been that inner opening for me.
And in all of the interviews you have done
now with over 80 people who are here in North
America who have taken ayahuasca, Westerners,
magical kinds of experiences of a wide variety
are common.
Right.
Right.
Very common.
So there was one ceremony for me where I had, I
know this is an old-fashioned term, a Rolodex,
and I could call people up on kind of a dial
phone and talk to them, people who had died.
So I'm happily going through my own address book, my inner Rolodex, and I'm talking to
people and I got blessings from one of my research mentors who had died a few decades
ago, and I'm having a great old time, and then I get a little egotistical about it,
and I try and call someone who was not in my direct circle, my close circle, and my
hand got slapped, and the whole process was
shut down, and grandmother ayahuasca basically
said to me, no, you're pushing it, you pushed
the limits, I'm shutting this off, and it
never opened up like that again.
And I, you know, I was put in my place and I
appreciate, I got a little egotistical about
it.
Well, let's talk to so-and-so, you know, let's
talk to Einstein, see what he has to say.
No, no, uh-uh, no.
So that was an interesting experience.
They're not all terrifying or horrible or
even mystical, some are just plain practical.
There's a teaching in that one for me.
Yeah, I got a little too curious.
Well, it's an ongoing active relationship.
Yes it is.
Uh-huh.
And you began this research quite a long time ago.
Almost a full decade ago.
The research itself took three years, another
year for it to be published, and then the
book took years to come together and really clarify what I wanted to say.
So this relationship that you have with Grandmother
Ayahuasca has been continuous and ongoing
for well over a decade.
I'm going to guess closer to two.
No, no, one decade is two.
Okay.
That's true, yeah.
That's still a decade is a healthy amount of time for you to be able to evaluate it.
Yes.
And so I have to say, if we look at the effects,
as you said, William James, what's the real,
the so-called real world proof of the pudding,
so to speak, is yes, I have really dedicated
this last decade to doing this research and the writing and talking about and trying to
understand how this works.
And because I've been a therapist most of
my life, that has been my lens through which
I viewed this medicine.
I mean, an anthropologist would do it much differently.
But there's something very therapeutic about
this relationship with Grandmother Ayahuasca
that's quite different.
And yet it did trigger, and we touched on
it briefly, maybe we can go into it a little
more depth, what you call an ontological crisis.
Yes.
Well, that phrase was developed by John Mack,
who's the Harvard psychiatrist who researched
all the abduction stories.
Yes.
Remember, he was hypnotizing people and helping them retrieve their experiences.
And he had no way to, no professional way to explain the material he was getting.
I mean, there have been a lot of mysteries that have come up, you know.
And so he talked about this crisis in meaning,
what do these stories mean that he himself
went through?
And he was a psychiatrist, and as I recall, he was a friend of mine as well.
Oh, you know everyone.
And he got in trouble at Harvard.
Indeed he did.
And at the end of the day, he concluded that
the reports of UFO abductees was akin to the
kinds of reports that come out of the shamanistic literature as well.
Yes.
Yes.
Hinting to other worlds.
Yeah.
The shamans have begun, you know, well, I
shouldn't say just the shamans, the one shaman
who retired as a vegetalisto, because Grandmother
Ayahuasca told him, stop working with this
medicine and paint your visions, and that's Pablo Amaringo.
And so he had a perfect recall of his visions
when he was in ceremonies, and so he painted
these gorgeous paintings.
But if you look carefully, many of the paintings have flying saucers in them.
You know, they have Middle Eastern architecture
in them, they're quite complex, but the flying
saucers are relatively new over the last couple of decades.
And it fits perfectly with the Ayahuasca cosmology.
You know, the shamans talking about being,
this is more indigenous, about being married
to pink dolphins who live in the rivers in
the Amazon, and, you know, having spirit wives
that they go and they stay with at the bottom
of the river and they live with, and...
This kind of war is why some of the 19th century
anthropologists assumed that shamanism was
a form of psychosis.
Yes, that was way back.
Yeah.
Well, now we're wanting to study what they know about the plants for medical purposes.
You know, we really treat each shaman now as a pharmaceutical library.
And not only that, we're taking a fresh look at the meaning of psychosis as well.
Yes, somewhat.
Somewhat.
Some of us.
Some of us are.
Yes.
Well, Wilson Van Dusen was a psychologist who wrote about the presence of spirits in
the world of madness.
Yes, that's a beautiful phrase.
Yeah.
And I remember working with someone who had
had a psychotic break during, or immediately
after a surgical procedure, which happens.
And in part it's a reaction to the anesthesia.
But it was really a mystical experience.
So if a psychologist was only working within
this conceptual consensus reality, they would
say, well, this is a drug reaction and, you
know, just how do you stabilize yourself and
get over this?
But it was a very meaningful experience for him, and it changed the way he saw his life
and the world.
And so when we talked about it, we talked about it much differently.
It opened things up for him.
Well, there is this tendency in Western culture,
and I think we're probably all, I'm going
to bet that every single viewer of this video
is guilty of it at one time or another, which
is to try and interpret these experiences from a materialistic framework.
Yes, that's our world.
And that training is rooted linguistically for us.
I mean, we really are, I know I am really locked into it, and that's part of why it's
such an ontological crisis for me to have relationships with this plant spirit.
Yeah, you know, my favorite thing about how language forms our reality and how we get
locked into it so early is the Native Americans that,
you know, the great mystery is the interpretation,
the translation of their phrase for a supreme
being, energy, whatever you want to call it.
But that's not quite right, because our language
is bound by nouns, we make nouns out of everything.
And their language, especially the Navajo language, is verb based.
So to be accurate, it should be the great mysterious thing.
Isn't that nice?
Yeah, I know you are inspired by my old friend Danny Alford.
Oh, really?
You know everyone.
I am inspired by this, absolutely.
Yeah, sometimes I feel like that song, I was
born about 10,000 years ago, and there's nothing
in this world that I don't know.
Or anybody you don't know.
Yeah.
Well, I don't want to get too egotistical
about it, but yeah, he was a beautiful spirit.
Yes, that comes through.
His point, that he ended up setting up conferences
between quantum physicists and Native American
elders.
Right.
And one of the key points that they both began
to agree upon is that reality is much more
like a verb than a noun.
Absolutely, and yes.
But we are so programmed to think in terms of nouns, it's quite limiting.
We think things.
Perfect.
Yeah.
And that gets us trapped into a kind of materialistic mindset.
I think materialism is great as a tool, not as a metaphysics.
Yes, not as everything.
Yeah, and so there's something about the ayahuasca
experience that opens up beyond our conditioning
in many ways.
I mean, this is the cultural ontological conditioning,
so it opens us up psychologically and also
philosophically.
Well, in a way, I think the whole psychedelic
revolution, it came along right at the heels
of the 1950s at a time when the crust of society
was weighed very, very thickly, and it just
sort of blew that whole crust off, and all of
a sudden you had a generation, my generation
to be honest, our generation, 20-year-old people
who were becoming mystics by the millions.
And we didn't really know how to translate that.
We had dreams of this will make a better world,
but we really didn't know how to translate
that, and I don't think we did so well at that.
I mean, if you saw the Haight-Ashbury section
of San Francisco during the heyday of the
love summer, and then saw it maybe two years
later where it was completely burned out and
filled with heroin and amphetamines, it was really a sad sight.
And so that's some of my stress on the
importance of what happens after the experience.
What do you do with this?
How has your life changed?
Can you integrate it?
Yes.
Right.
Well, Rachel Harris, you have done a fine job exemplifying
how it can be integrated, and for that I thank
you very much.
Thank you very much.
It's been a pleasure being with you for these interviews.
Thank you, Jeffrey.
And thank you for being with us.
